column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref

#Text=[0065] To examine the quantitative effects of the embodiments of the present invention in improving the nonwoven fabric 110 strength, the samples' tear resistance was evaluated in the processing direction 5 and compared to corresponding tear strength of the control fabric.
#Text=The tear test measures the force required to tear a textile specimen in which a tear is initiated prior to testing.

#Text=More particularly, according to ASTM D2261-96 "Standard Test Method for Tearing Strength of Fabrics by the Tongue (Single Rip) Procedure (Constant-Rate-of-Extension Tensile Testing Machine)" a rectangular specimen (75 mm.times.200 mm) of the nonwoven fabric 110 was precut in the center of the long edge to form a two-tongued or "trouser-shaped" specimen.
#Text=One tongue was clamped into the lower jaw of the machine and the other was clamped into the upper jaw.
#Text=During the measurement, the distance between the jaws increases and the force applied to the fabric, due to the movement of the jaws, propagates the tear.
#Text=FIGS. 15A-15B shows two specimens representing the rupture propagation in the control and "sample-110" nonwoven fabrics 110.
#Text=It can be seen that the rupture propagates along the ridges 300 ("jet streaks") in the case of control fabrics (see FIG. 15A).
#Text=This is because the jet-streaks create areas of minimum resistance which are generally aligned in the processing direction 5.
#Text=The rupture front in the case of sample-110 (see FIG. 15B), however, did propagate in a straight line.
#Text=Tear in this case tends to follow a path of minimum resistance which is not necessarily in the processing direction 5.
#Text=[0066] During the tear test, the force required to move the clamps was also recorded.
#Text=FIG. 16 shows the force-strain curves obtained from conducting the tear test on five (5) replicates of the control and "sample-110" nonwoven fabrics 110.
#Text=The results were normalized with the average resistance of the control fabric for a better comparison.
#Text=An improvement of about 25% (and, in some cases, up to 50%) in the tear resistance of the fabric produced using embodiments of the present invention is evident.
#Text=Similar tests have also been performed on "sample-100", "sample-120", and "sample-130," which were also produced using various embodiments of the present invention.
#Text=These results are generally in agreement with the results of the co-occurrence experiment, and reveal that "sample-110" has the most uniform surface and the highest tear resistance.

#Text=The load values increase rapidly with the strain and reach a plateau after an elongation of about 100% where they start fluctuating until the specimen nonwoven fabric 110 is completely ruptured.
#Text=The initial increase in the load is the force needed to bring the fabric under tension without the rupture front moving.
#Text=The tear resistance is averaged from the point where the rupture front starts moving towards the end of specimen (i.e., at about 100% elongation), until failure occurs.
#Text=The average load of the control fabric is may be used to normalize the tear resistance of all the samples for better comparison.
#Text=The average normalized tear resistances of the samples and their corresponding standard deviations are shown in Table 1 below.
#Text=[0067] As one skilled in the art will appreciate, it is important that hydroentangled fabrics maintain their strength against tensile load.
#Text=It is important to ensure that amending the tear resistance of the fabrics does not damage their tensile properties.

#Text=For this reason all the nonwoven fabric 110 samples produced using exemplary embodiments of the present invention were examined using the tensile test methods outlined in ASTM D 5035-95 entitled "Standard Test Method for Breaking Force and Elongation of Textile Fabrics (Strip Method)".
#Text=This test reports the force required to tear a textile specimen in the tensile direction.

#Text=In accordance with this method, a rectangular specimen (25 mm.times.150 mm) of the nonwoven fabric 110 is mounted on the upper and lower jaw of a tensile testing machine with its long dimension parallel to the direction of force application.
#Text=The distance between the jaws is increased until the break of the fabric occurs, caused by the force applied to the specimen.
#Text=The force required to break the textile specimen and the elongation of the specimen are reported during the measurement.
#Text=[0068] FIG. 17 shows the force-strain curves obtained from conducting the above-referenced tensile test on 5 replicates of the control and sample-110 nonwoven fabrics 110.
#Text=These results are normalized with the maximum average tensile strength of the control nonwoven fabric for a better comparison.
#Text=FIG. 17 reveals that there is no
#Text=substantial change in the tensile properties of the sample-110 in the processing direction 5.
#Text=The normalized average tensile strengths of the sample-100, sample-120, and sample-130 are shown in Table 2 for comparison.
#Text=The vales are normalized using the average maximum (at rupture) tensile strength of the control fabric for a better comparison.
#Text=It is evident that none of the sample fabrics show any substantial reduction in their tensile properties.
